data.title: Berkeley Preparatory School
data.meta_description: The National Hispanic Scholar Awards program has named Mayia Chaumont, Paul Hadden, Asune Laca, Juan Carlos Martinez and Adrienne Riofrio of Berkeley Preparatory School as semifinalists in the...
data.text:
The National Hispanic Scholar Awards program has named Mayia Chaumont, Paul Hadden, Asune Laca, Juan Carlos Martinez and Adrienne Riofrio of Berkeley Preparatory School as semifinalists in the National Hispanic Scholar Awards Program. They were selected on the basis of their performance on the 1991 PSAT last fall.

Chamberlain High School

Phil Snow, a 1992 graduate of Chamberlain, was a state finalist in a state video competition. He placed first in video documentary. He attends the University of South Florida and is majoring in video communications and technical theater. The Amoco Corp. has presented a grant of $750 to the Chamberlain mentor group. The check was presented to James Gatlin, principal, by Ken Brinson of Amoco. The money will be used to purchase books to take to "at risk" first-graders at Forest Hills Elementary School. Chamberlain students will read with first-graders and give them the books to take home. The grant was written by Betty Watson, reading resource specialist at Chamberlain.

The Chamberlain High drama department and Thespian Troupe 165 will present the drama Flowers for Algernon at 7:30 p.m. Oct. 1, 2 and 3 in the auditorium. David Cox has the lead with Jennifer Aaron, co-starring. Others in the play are Todd Messner, Jon Murden, Tami Bulmash, Michael Fox, Amy Williams, Kim Borton, Dana Connolly, Eric Pages, Jimmy Acevedo, John Brogan, Ben Gibbson, Samantha Grahn, Sheryl Frye, Maria Burgos, Kelly Greenwood, Kelly Benjamin, Joe Gonzales, Jaime Graives, Mandi Anderson, Amina Jamai, Christie Williams, Mark Smith, Kim Shafer, Thu Luu, Chris Davis, Natalie Campisi, Shayla Prezas, Cydney Sizeler, Roy Wiley, Laurie New, Kristyn Williamson, Casey Sandford, Vanessa Thorpe, Dervla Reilly, Sabrina Steele, Hanna Szemso, Dawn Delatorre and Cedra Malmud.

Tickets are available at the door. For information call 932-6141.

Officers for the student council are Max Ferrara, president; Melinda Fallieres, vice president; Jennifer Fisher, recording secretary; Melissa Slocum, corresponding secretary; Rebecca Driscoll, treasurer; and Kathy Nerro, historian.

Academy of the Holy Names

Deanna Tindale, a ninth-grader, and Emmett Doerr, an eighth-grader, were accepted for the summer programs offered by the Joseph Baldwin Academy for Eminent Young Scholars on the campus of Northeast Missouri State University. They were selected on the SAT scores. Deanna took a writing course and Emmett studied French. Seventh-graders Melanie Fernandez and David Powell were selected to participate in the USF Governors' Summer Leadership Program. Seven new trustees have begun serving their term. They are Margo B. Hammar, Nancy H. Harris, Dr. Lazaro Hernandez, the Rev. Frank M. Mouch, George Risleing, Elinor Sevigny and Kay Culbreath Young.

Plant High School

Elizabeth Burdick, Fabiola Crovetto, Melissa Garcia and Lorisa Lorenzo are semifinalists in the National Hispanic Scholars Award program. They are among the 3,082 seniors in the United States and Puerto Rico designated as semifinalists based on qualifying PSAT scores.

New faculty members at Plant are Kristy Keller, Laurie Jones, Donna Rothell, Sallie Lemus, John Niemtus, Sandra Schmidt, Kim Sheridan-Caro, John Tamborello, Lisa Blowers, Dan Hartung, Rachel McCaskill, Leslie Skinner, Janice Van Glahn, Bernice Craig, Maria Palios, Beverly Simpson, Margarita Laguado de'Gomez, Kathryn Rizzo, Myriam Santiago-Esfahani, George Goff, Roy Harrison, Marcia Saffold, Janet Wright, Paul Michael, Joseph Thomas and Linda Price-Rance.

Orange Grove Elementary

An attendance grant of $700 from the Hillsborough County Educational Partnership Foundation has been awarded to Orange Grove. The grant is named for the Gator mascot and is called "Be an EarlyGator, not a TailGator." The grant has made provisions for a schoolwide competition where the teachers become "InvestiGATORS" and reward the class with the best attendance. On behalf of T.G. Lee Foods, Orange Grove's computer lab has the opportunity to earn funds to purchase computer software. Through Dec. 31 the school will receive 5 cents for every gallon cap from a T.G. Lee gallon of milk. The school has set a goal of 1,000 caps.

Tampa Preparatory School

Twenty students at Tampa Preparatory School have been named AP Scholars by the College Board in recognition of their exceptional achievement on the college-level Advanced Placement Exams. This figure represents 25 percent of last year's senior class. There are three levels of achievement: AP Scholar with Distinction, AP Scholar with Honor and the AP Scholar. At Tampa Prep nine students qualified for the AP Scholar with Distinction: Robert Bird (UF); Heidi Curran (Harvard); Joshua Ewen (Brown); Jennifer Farmer (Duke); Pam McDonald (Harvard); John Michael Raymond (UCF); Jeffrey Williamson (Georgetown); and Nathaniel Yangco (Yale). Two qualified for the AP Scholar: Quinby Dobbins (Georgetown) and Linda Hower (Wellesley). Nine qualified for the AP Scholar: Alison Angell (Bates); April Berton (Converse); Ian Davidaon (UF); Andela DiMaria (Goucher); Gary Djeu (in 12th grade); Dinny Fahey (Vanderbilt); Jessica Powers (American University); Kelly Simonsen (Lehigh); and Matt Warren (12th grade).
